posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Your college "professor" is clearly not qualified to answer the question and should merely have told you so.

I'm going to give you a simplified answer, yet more accurate, to help you get some basic understanding behind the motivation to invade USSR.


>1. No where left to go
When France was defeated, Germany found herself in an ackward spot in its war with Britain. As Britain was a naval superpower and Germany was a army superpower, neither could effectively hit the other. Germany had no realistic chance on the planet to ever invade Britain as Germany had no surface fleet, amphibious landing doctrine, no industry to create one, no training to draw upon, no means to maintain supply and logistics for one, and most importantly, no ability what so ever to defeat the insanely powerful Royal Navy.

Meanwhile, the British are in less of a hurry to invade Germany. The Royal Navy is now effectively blocking Germany from all world trade of vital imports such as oil, food, copper, rubber, cotton, fodder, industrial ore, textiles etc.
German economy was also slowly drained from the weight of her many occupied nations that also required these imports, and the cost of maintaining a military occupation (Norway alone required 100.000 troops to be stationed).
The British were also conducting a more successful bombing campaign as the Royal Airforce was steadily growing stronger than her German counterpart.
The British SOE were also successfully infiltrating occupied territory, training resistance movements that would further strain German economy.

The British were also slowly defeating Germanys ally Italy in the Mediteranian, having already delivered a crushing blow to the Italian navy at Tarano.

So what then?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>2. Now or Never
By the time of the fall of France, the german military was to say the least, in a victory frenzy. Germany never expected the French to surrender, and certainly not as quickly as they did. There was a feeling of undefeatable morale among german troops and command, their men has reach an ability and training that could possibly never be matched again.
However, the german mobilised army was very big, and upkeep was an issue. If the war with Britain would be of air dominance, naval Uboat campaigns, and localised offshore battles, where does the remaining 90% of the army go? To demobilise would be seen as a massive squander of a great opportunity with such an effective force.

Now also take into consideration that there was a time window with military of the USSR.
While the German army performance and confidence was at all-time high, the USSR likewise was at its poorest following their war with Finland, and the USSR were rushing to retrain, reorganise, rearm, reeducate her military. Germany knew this.
Germany knew that in a couple of years, the Red Army will its own mechanized divsion again, an effective doctrine, a structure that has corrected its previous failures, and men better trained and prepared.
But as of now, it wouldnt stand a chance against the German army.

posts.name: Anonymous

Germany and USSR never trusted each others despite agreements, and both knew war was inevitable eventually. Should USSR one day fight Germany, her oilfields would be immediately captured.
Stalin had also ordered all frontline armies and fortifications to be moved as close to the new borders with Germany (following the divide of Poland) as possible.

I read somewhere a theory that the Odin figure was an incorrectly assigned title. It states, effectively, Odin was a term designating High King or Chief of Chiefs, pulling from specific references made regarding the Germanic invasion of Rome. It states that these bands gathered together in coordinated attack seemingly from nowhere with no particular instigation against them all simultaneously, leading this individual to belief that they were rallied by a single man or rather the efforts of a single man, titled Odin.
From there it argues that Odin, possibly being a title, was assigned to the god Wodinn, as he was the chief of gods, but it was not his name. Similar to the use of words designating "Lord" that fit for Carthaginian/Phoenician gods. It would then be theorized that because of linguistic and cultural differences that the figure Wodinn was misunderstood and over time inherited the faculties of other gods. Or that Odin, Chief of Chiefs, described multiple gods over a period of time like the various Kings of old, with differing specialties and personalities that then became the soup of one figure.

I do not assign value to the theory as good or bad, merely as interesting enough to share.

*Wōðanaz evolve from a demon of the wild hunt into a worshipped deity
Anatoly Lieberman made a god sum of this.
According to an ancient belief, a procession of dead bodies flew through the air or rode on horseback. Such a procession was called *wōðu- […] The demon chasing the dead, or in other tales leading them, could have a theriomorphic form: half man, half horse (or he could be a man eating a horse. […] The demon of the *wōðu- was also called *wōðu-. Various reflexes of this name turned up in the Modern West and North Germanic languages. […] Later, individual demons (supernatural objects of cults) gained in prominence, and a special suffix of Indo-European origin began to be used in their names. This is how *Wōðanaz came into being…
In terms of timeline, Liberman says:
Assuming that *Wōðanaz was [an active god of death and a great war god], he must have achieved this status on the continent before Tacitus.
And also:
By the time Tacitus’s informants began recording West Germanic higher mythology, *Wōðanaz had become an anthropomorphic deity surrounded by other gods, all of whom could be compared with the gods of the Romans.

What I will add is that for Odin to have attained his place of prominence by the time of Tacitus, and also for him to have transformed from a theriomorphic being into an anthropomorphic one that point, IMO, that would probably indicate an “earliest” origin of at least a couple thousands of years earlier, if not much longer.

Before I refute OP's particular attack on the Christian faith I want to stress the weight of the objection by illustrating how unsatisfactory Dirk's response is. The underlying presupposition here is that a proposition which has not yet been proven or disproven is assumed to be false. I imagine this is an unwitting influence from atheism, since Christians have far too often allowed the atheists in that dispute to lessen the burden of proof which they bear by letting them justify their professed unbelief in God by claiming there has been insufficient evidence to prove His existence; however it is mistaken that a proposition not proven or disproven is assumed to be false, it is assumed to have a truth value equal to its negation. So perhaps the atheist has succeeded in justifying his own personal unbelief, but at the same time he has succeeded in stripping himself of any basis to object to the Christian's belief, since his unbelief apparently has no more evidentiary basis than belief. Likewise, if our sole response to the tranny is that he has not proven his case, perhaps we are vindicated in not embracing his perversion, but we have also vindicated him in not repudiating it.

>When the waterworks came under city jurisdiction in 1869 in the Reconstruction Era, the man named Superintendent of the New Orleans City Water Works was a former Confederate General, Braxton Bragg. >On Bragg’s staff as assistant superintendent was a remarkable man. Edmond Rillieux was one of the children of a Free Woman of Color, Constance Vivant, and the white man with whom she was placéed (in common law marriage), Vincent Rillieux, who was the uncle of the French Impressionist painter, Edgar Degas. >The letter-books of the Water Works are filled with familiar-sounding complaints, mostly addressed to the luckless Rillieux: “Water box in appurtenance of Dryades Market is out of order, Please have it repaired,” reads a curt note from April 1, 1872; and the next day, April 2, “please have the party who does the paving for the Water Works to make the repairs necessary to the banquettes (sidewalks) fronting or bordering on the DeSoto School.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14331890
Castles in Italy were much later arriving than other areas of Europe, as much more of the population was urban compared to France Germany Spain or England. The first “castles” were just fortified cities with an imperial palace. Most buildings in Italy were retained from Roman times or rebuilt using spolia, material from collapsed Roman buildings. Churches stuck closer to Roman basilica styles, resulting in the Romanesque architerctural style which lasted for much longer in Italy. Wood buildings were rare and would have been mostly in the countryside and temporary, constructed by nomadic invaders. Brick buildings were common, with new medieval buildings using half timbered style, but much less so than anywhere else in Europe. Even in the countryside peoples houses were mostly built with brick or stones. A great surviving example is the Apulian trullo, a stone country house that can be built or demolished I a couple of days (in the past this was done to avoid paying property tax). Incastellamento was a mostly southern Italian phenomenon brought by the normans who were culturally Frankish and as such were rural lords used to living in fortified villas in the countryside. In the north the nobles lived in cities and tried to control the urban population as much as possible.

>Were the castles and churches largely the same as their northern neighbors?
In short answer, yes. Spain basically adopted the same architectural styles as its northern neighbor France, you find romanesque and gothic buildings just like there, but here the style is usually adopted to the iberian tastes with flat pitch roofs, less verticality, a more austere exterior decoration and more horizontality. Also Spain was a hostile frontier, so a lot of churches at the time were fortified for military reasons. Pic of Villamorón, with a bizarre fortified gothic XIII century church.

>>14331890
Winters in the north of Spain can get quite chilly, homes there resembled much of medieval Europe, wattle and daub and a thatched roof. In the south adobe predominated with adobe plaster or thatched roofs depending on the particulars of the climate and resources available.

In the cities timber framing could add storeys, but timber and thatch were fire hazards and there was more impetus to move to stone load bearing walls and terracotta roofing like the Roman cities.

The four chimpanzees subspecies diverged from each other over 400,000 years ago (with the western chimpanzee being the most divergent at 600kya from the rest), which is roughly equivalent to the most conservative split between Homo sapiens and Homo neanderthalensis, and chimpanzees also have far more genetic diversity than modern humans do, not just from general divergence but also through admixture events of their own combined with far longer stages of isolation. Bonobos interbred with chimpanzees, as did a ghost species of chimpanzee that no longer exists.

>at an ever-diminishing well of manpower that *would've replenished* if they weren't fucking burning it on constant warfare and taxing shit to hell and back.
Your fatal lack of understanding of massive difference between Central Italian culture in the Republic and Empire is showing. The amount of men from Central Italy mobilised reached something about 30% in the Republic, by the 2nd century it was less than 5%.
>They didn't really seem to understand currency, very much, either, what with all the debasement
They understood it very well, most people on here don't seem to understand that debasement is not a bad thing per se. It increases the amount of coin available to the Emperor to use. The attempt to increase purity in coinage was usually a bad thing for the Emperor, as in the reigns of Valens and Valentinian when they had to sell Imperial estates to make up for the loss in real Imperial revenue.
> locking people into their professions on a generation-to-generation basis
This only actually applied to the Army and the Curial class and was easy enough to circumvent.
>capping prices into place
These have quite literally always existed. Diocletian's price controls were an extreme version of what they already had, and it didn't last and wasn't even implemented in most places.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14337939
Homosexuality existed in ancient Greece, though sources don't mention it up until the archaic period, afaik there's no bronze age Greek source that references homosexuality.
It usually took the form of pederasty, with a high status man having sex with a low status boy or teenager. Sparta seems to have been the only city to actively criminalize pederasty, in the laws of Lycurgus.
Geographically, it seems that homosexuality was most common in the cities of Boeotia and Attica, more so than in other regions in the Greek world, but this might be due to the fact that most of our sources for the Classical period come from Athens.
Overall homosexuality wasn't persecuted and it didn't ruin someone's reputation, but it wasn't universal and there were detractors who spoke against it. It probably was a controversial topic back then.
I think the case of Plato is particularly interesting, in his earlier works he talks positively about homosexuality as a form of love, but in his last work he changed his opinion and deemed it unnatural and the product of lust, not love, and that, thus, it should be banned.
Regarding the famous sacred band of Thebes, our source claiming that it was composed of 150 pairs of male lovers is Plutarch, writing 400 years after the dissolution of the band. Make of that what you will.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>father
They had a common paternal ancestor that lived thousands of years earlier, so not really. Also later Corded Ware had R1a haplogroup which branched off from R1b some 20,000 years ago.

At the same time both groups were genetically very similar. We are talking about patrilocal clans of semi-pastoral groups living somewhere in East Europe. Their cultures were related and interacted with each other.
Both probably came from Sredni Stog, but one group became mobile pastoralists and domesticated horses - Repin/Yamnaya, while another expanded to Central Europe - Corded Ware.

>>14336124
Oh, I used Platonist to differentiate from the other Anon.
I asked that question because basically of the same doubts you're citing (but I think it was with corn?). Regardless, my issue was the apparent fluidity between the real entities vs their static (?) corresponding ideals.

One answer I found for a different question altogether, that curiously comes close to the idea that every lifeform is its own iteration, is cladistics. Basically, beings are organized according to the characteristics they have, which is solid enough to separate a horse from say, the horse-like ancestor or the horse-like descendant, but not enough as ultimately, "horse" is defined according to a set of unfixed characteristics. Also, because "horse" is now a group instead of an individual animal, all living horses, past present and future, are bound to share most but not all of the hypothetical perfect horse.

Another, much more unfun answer, was the postmodern idea that words work in networks, so you can't separate the word horse from what defines what it is. Every single word in any given language is then ultimately connected, and thus it's a nightmare to properly define, if that's even possible, horse A from horse B.

>>14336953
I looked into this question of why nobody just kept sailing along the African coast.

If you go along the coast you get to Cape Bojador, a headland off the Western Sahara. It looks insignificant, but once you go around it the wind changes direction and there are very strong currents, which made it a shipwreck blackspot. It was considered impassable.

The Portuguese realised that to pass it you have to sail well out to sea and then back in again on the circular 'Trade Winds' and it was only in the 1400s that they discovered the nautical technology to go well out into the Ocean. It's this tech that enabled the Age of Discovery.

Hope that helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It stands for Non-Aggression Principle and it's the backbone of the legal system as envisioned by Libertarians. Essentially, leave people alone unless they're actively causing harm to others, is the overarching guiding ideal. There's a range of interpretations of this ideal based on how averse different people are to the existence of regulation and government. For people who consider themselves to be anarchists, they'll try to abolish as many government institutions as they can. But in the United States, mainstream Libertarians are fine with government in principle, they just want its regulatory apparatuses trimmed down (i.e. auditing and closing down some bureaus), and many of its prohibitive laws repealed.

The Libertarian ideal in the US can be summarized as a desire to remove bureaucratic institutions which exist largely to exact fines and fees from people by passing an ever increasing amount of prohibitions on the public, and replace them with courts that serve to redress and mediate disputes between citizens.

A major tenet of Libertarian belief is that democratic processes are fundamentally subject to corruption so it is better to disperse effective power as widely as possible to mitigate the effects of corruption and to also make corrupt officials more immediately answerable to the people. Centralizing power means you only have to bribe a handful of people to pass sweeping legislation that covers the whole country. Decentralizing means you now have to bribe potentially hundreds of people, and get them to coordinate across dozens of different legislatures. And these officials might not be as keen on selling out their constituents when they are actually neighbors with them and will have these people quite literally on their doorstep if they pass something people don't like. Corruption will still happen, it just won't be a huge ordeal that requires a national effort to overturn, it can be handled in city hall.

>>14336455
this mostly explains it, but it also must be noted that Carter's post-presidency career was defined principally by philanthropic endeavors, especially of an Evangelical Christian bent. Many of the religious Reagan era conservatives who voted against Carter nevertheless respected his beliefs. His consistent track record of civic engagement since then has only softened the public's evaluation of his legacy.

My father was just coming out of grad school and looking for employment during the early 80s and was as critical of Carter as most people due to the economic crisis. However, in recent years he confided in me that Carter was simply ill-acquainted with the logistics of the macroeconomic policy and was dealt "a bad hand" in terms of the Iranian revolution.


Having studied U.S. history with some depth, specifically from 1900 onward, I still think that his "Crisis of Confidence" speech perfectly captures the malaise and disillusionment with 'liberalism' and authority in general that was affecting the American public after Watergate. He challenged the country to remove its dollar-value spectacles, tune out the mantras of consumerism, and revitalize what remained of its national spirit. Of course, for better or worse, the voters chose Reagan, deregulation, and the outsourcing of jobs to foreign labor markets. Capital investment certainly benefited, and the removed red tape allowed for the explosive growth of the tech industry and Silicon Valley. But I'm meandering now.

Regardless, Carter's presidency and the era of the 1970s will forever be a watershed in the USA's history.

posts.com: Hello friends, this year I have become a Christian and have been studying the Bible and praying personally but have yet to join a Church. It all seems so confusing that there are so many different Christian denominations, and I believe Christians should be united. Can anyone offer some advice or specify what the major differences are?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hi OP I'd like to give you an unbiased answer because these kinds of threads devolve quickly
Christian denominations can be explained simply as follows:
The Catholics and Orthodox agree on who the original church was (when Jesus founded it in Matthew 16:18), but there was only one church until 1054, when the Great Schism happened and the one church split into two, the Catholics (Romans) and the Orthodox (Byzantines).
These two churches disagreed on a variety of issues which you can read about with a quick search if you're interested.
In 1517, a man named Martin Luther nailed his 95 theses to a cathedral and some other dramatic shit happened and Lutheranism was born. This was the first Protestant denomination. After Lutheranism was established, this is where things got out of hand. Some of the other earlier denominations from the next 200 years would be the Anglicans, the Methodist, and the Baptist.
You see, Luther had rebelled against the state and political power of the Catholic Church, which he viewed as inherently corrupt. Because Luther broke away from the Catholic church, his new church would not require Catholic law, permitting him to make his own rules as he saw fit according to his theological reasoning. This has led to a snowball effect ever since, which is why there are now over 40,000 denominations in the world, all of which ARE considered Protestant. Yes this also means "nondenominationals", they are still Protestant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Catholic and Orthodox churches have what is called "Apostolic Succession" which is where they can trace their history back to Peter in the Bible. The first church (Pentecost-1054) was the first to print the Bible.
Many people view the Catholic, Orthodox, and early Protestant theological views as correct and for many differing reasons. Really, there is so much to argue over, like Mary, once saved always saved, the nature of christology, the whore of Babylon, etc. You're going to have to study very hard and make up your own mind on which theology you find most accurate, correct, and righteous because all aforementioned churches have many centuries of compelling arguments, councils, and works. It can take years to settle where you feel like you belong and which denomination is right but don't forget God is there and will help you. I have personally experienced several denominations and I liked the Catholics the best but they do have a lot of internal issues and a shady past. But Jesus warned us about thus.
Above all else, avoid crazy churches. Don't go to one where they use snakes on people, don't try to find deep metaphysical understanding in pastor jims sunday funday, and don't walk around with a signs protesting military funerals. Your journey will require great effort, searching, and understanding new ideas about an ancient and rich history, but its all fun and you'll get to be bigbrained by the end of it. Good luck OP.

Herbert Marcuse visited his ex-teacher Martin Heidegger in his Black Forest hut in 1947. here's what HM wrote to MH (8/28/47):

"Many of us have long awaited a statement from you, a statement that would clearly and finally free you from...identification [with the Nazi regime]. But you have never uttered such a statement... I—and very many others—have admired you as a philosopher; from you we have learned an infinite amount. But we cannot make the separation between Heidegger the philosopher and Heidegger the man.. The viceroyalties were always supposed to essentially function as an extension of the Spanish kingdoms. They had governors who were encouraged to take some liberties in how they administrated their respective regions. As time passed and the empire declined, they could no longer project any power in their far-off territories and logically the people there began to identify with their immediate community rather than some King thousands of miles away. Colonials were also dependent on local garrisons of Spanish soldiers, which meant those n the empty frontier lacked protection, but they also lacked an official government authority to enforce the codified law. It wasn't a bar

said the land wasn't a blank slate across which settlement and development were uniform. For example, the Spanish settlers living in what is now the SW United States had to deal with Comanche raids and harsh drought as opposed to, say, some comfy urbanite in Mexico City or Veracruz.
They had eventually come to be dependent on cattle ranching (there wasn't much else and the government had effectively abandoned them) by 1830 and fraternized with Anglos, which the Spanish government wouldn't have likeD if they were still in charge. Many of them refused to identify with Mexico or the empire and to this day refer to themselves as "Hispanos" or "Tejanos" according to local cultural ties rather than a greater polity.

>>14337272
>Was there a financial incentive, running from the law, treasure hunters, etc?
Remember that I'm only talking about Mexico here since it's the land I'm most knowledgeable of.

In the initial decades of conquest, most men in the colonies were either priests or soldiers. Spain had just gotten out of a 700 year war with Muslims and they expected the threat to return in the near future. Non-military men were usually friars of various orders who arrived to baptize the indians and integrate them to modern life. The military was there to enforce imperial ambitions and ensure that any resources found were Spanish property.

As the colonies grew, the culture changed. Initially the social dynamics were structured around large land grants given to successful conquistadors and nobility who had indians working the lands as sharecroppers.

This didn't last: many natives died off in the 1600s mostly due to disease but also because of being worked to death and there was a shortage of labor.
More black slaves were imported and Spanish settlers from the mainland were encouraged to immigrate through various means in order to boost the population, especially since so few women actually accompanied the men, who were mostly single military aged males.

For example: an unmarried Spanish woman could own and manage her own property. Many people were given land grants by the government if they were wealthy or deserving enough.
You could argue that early Spanish settlers were treasure hunters. Many doubtlessly fled the scene of a crime, and supposedly many conversos( converted Jews and non-Spaniards) took refuge there in the 18th century but I can't remember where I read that. Later arrivals were lower class peasants


Spaniards moved to the colonies for many of the same reasons Anglos did except maybe religious persecution.

>Investigations of ancient quarry sites and of numerous cut-stone walls reveal that the amazing Inca constructions were built with very simple means. To dress the stones smaller hammerstones were used to pound them until they had the desired shape. The fitting of one stone to another was done by cutting the already laid stones to receive the next ones in a trial-and-error fashion. posts.com: but to summarise, it was a mixture of very, very fine chiselling and smoothing with hammers, scraping with a flint microlith to remove pitting and chips and the use of rubbing mud onto the granite to create a glass finish, with the minerals and coarseness of the mud scouring the surface "not unlike a jeweler's rouge used for polishing glass today" 12 hours of polishing for a small piece of granite, expand that to a pillar or statue and we're talking significant effort

>The pyramid of Djoser (or Djeser and Zoser), sometimes called the Step Pyramid of Djoser, is an archaeological site in the Saqqara necropolis, Egypt, northwest of the ruins of Memphis. I think it's important to keep in mind that the thirteen colonies and Australia were shitholes.

That's not some 'America le bad' bait, so I'll elaborate. See, the Caribbean was ludicrously profitable, but you didn't send more Europeans there than you strictly needed to administer the plantations and ship goods off. Similarly, the Spanish conquests on the continent were already conveniently organized into taxable, exploitable empires that shat out precious metals and other goods easily without having to import more men than strictly needed to run the place (into the ground, lmao). Further, the land that would become Canada might be a frigid waste, but it had lots of furs and other such valuable goods - but that, too, did not require much in the way of mass colonization to profit off of. Just some trading posts and native partners, and there you go. And that's just the new world. The Old World was already replete with human populations that could be easily (if brutally) mobilized to pull resources out of the ground or grow crops or whatever your imperial dreams demanded of them. They didn't settle their colonies because there wasn't a *point* to settling those colonies. Empire is about making the big bucks, not expanding one's ethnic footprint.

The English did settler shit in areas where it was necessary to get value from the land. You'll notice that most other British colonies, the ones don't today have large white populations, were the more profitable ones, yes?

>>14333248
I'm not pagan, and I don't recommend becoming pagan, and I do not believe that paganism is, strictly speaking, "right" in the sense that Christianity is.

However, the honest intention of primitive human beings trying to come to grips with the physical and metaphysical world as expressed in the more benign forms of paganism (which, itself, cannot have an organized mythology or institutions if they are the domain of the true pagans, i.e. the rustic country people) is not ipso facto bad.
When the Mycenaean vintner of 2,000 BC praised Dionysus for delivering a healthy harvest of grapes, this was not a bad thing. When a Norsewoman thanked Freyja for a successful childbirth, this was not a bad thing. But it is only good insofar as it comes from a sincere folk belief unadulterated by phony institutionalized ritual, codified by dramatists, or disassociated from all continuity with the sincere belief by a gap of a thousand or more years.

If you are sincerely interested in paganism as a virtue, your best bet is to closely examine the traditional religions of Amerindians, the Yazidis, Australian Aboriginals, Polynesians, African tribes, East Asians, or Hindus. The Western Tradition of paganism is lost, and people trying to restore it on the basis of the Greeks or the Norse or the Celts or the Slavs are, at best, fighting a losing battle with reality, or at worst, atheist charlatans using the veneer of religion to mask political harangues.

This is a shared sentiment among people who have been fed relentless anti-european propaganda. The only thing which is in our way to restore these traditions is the collective nihilism of the modern age and the laziness of irreligious urbanites. We have more than enough sources on rituals, customs, beliefs, and deities, and if something is missing we can cross-reference it with the most documented traditions to fill in the blanks. What matters is not whether your reconstruction is 100% accurate, but whether you can commune with the Gods through your experiences. Religion is a living practice required to connect your intellect to the spiritual world, not an unchanging monolithic creed that can no longer be recovered if you can't make an exact replica of what the practices were like in 3000 BC.

>>14331813
https://catholicstraightanswers.com/why-does-jesus-refer-to-the-canaanite-woman-as-a-dog/

The passage in question occurs in Matthew 15:21-28. Our Lord is approached by a gentile Canaanite woman (also called the Syro-Phoenician woman) whose daughter is possessed by a demon. On first hearing their conversation, Our Lord definitely seems hostile and uncompassionate; however, to draw such a conclusion is contrary to who Jesus is.

This passage is indeed complicated. Understanding the cultural context will help. First, Jesus’ mission was first to the people of the covenant, i.e., the Jews, who were awaiting the Messiah. Technically, the mission to the gentiles was not granted until the Ascension, when Our Lord said, “Go out and make disciples of all the nations” (Mt 28:18-20). Nevertheless, He already had shown His openness to the gentiles, like curing the centurion’s serving boy (Mt 8:5-13).

Second, Jews considered gentiles as “dogs.” To call a person a “dog” was a severe insult. The Jews used phrases like, “gentile dog,” “infidel dog” and later, “Christian dog.” However, Jesus used the diminutive form for “dog,” better translated as “puppy.” So instead of calling her the insulting “junk yard dog,” He calls her “lovable puppy.” (Keep in mind the English translation misses this distinction from the original Greek text.)

https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2015%3A21-28%2CMark%207%3A24-30&version=NIV
